We may address it in future experiments in order to speed them up, 
but I p=
robably would not make it the focus of a publication because 
its solution =
is likely fairly straightforward, i.e. not that deep in 
a research sense. =
Also, the problem of revisiting the same points is 
known in stochastic alg=
orithms already.

The most obvious way to address the problem is simply to =
compare 
new genomes with what's come before.  Of course, such comparisons =

become increasingly expensive as the generations increase, and at 
some po=
int, it becomes cheaper simply to evaluate everyone rather 
than try to fig=
ure out who is a repeat.  Depending on available 
resources, you can progra=
m it to look for duplicates as long as it's 
computationally advantageous. =
 It may turn out not very useful for 
most of the run.

There is a potentia=
l for more sophisticated appraches, e.g. maybe 
some kind of hashing scheme=
, but they would need to promise 
sufficiently impressive results to justif=
y their effort.  I am not 
sure how much effort is justified by a 10% impro=
vement.  I am 
guessing work has been done on this problem before outside o=
f NEAT, 
but I don't know about it offhand.

ken
